title: Hong Kong protest leader pleads for Australia to back democracy
text:
"It's a real life or death matter because the police have used live ammunition.

"All these actions [by the police and armed mobs], they're not having any legal consequences at all."

Ms Leung, vice-convener of the Hong Kong Civil Human Rights Front, said the international community including Australia needed to send a strong message to both the Hong Kong and Chinese governments that their behaviour was unacceptable.

Doing business with China now is like feeding a monster. When you keep feeding it, it will get bigger and bigger. — Bonnie Leung, pro-democracy protester

While some countries may be worried that criticism could cost them access to the lucrative Chinese market, Ms Leung said unity was crucial because "China has a habit of if one country is not kowtowing, they will work to benefit the ones who are silent".

Ms Leung warned that if Beijing was allowed to get away with breaking the One Country, Two Systems principle and undermine democratic rights that were enshrined in Hong Kong's Basic Law and handover agreement between Britain and China, it would continue to push international norms.

"What we're seeing in Hong Kong is a visualisation of how bad, how bullying China can be," she said.

"Doing business with China now is like feeding a monster. When you keep feeding it, it will get bigger and bigger.

Ms Leung will give a private address to Parliament's foreign affairs and defence committee as well as MPs who belong to the cross-party Parliamentary Friends of Democratic Hong Kong group.

She will highlight a bill passed by the US House of Representatives this week, which requires an annual review of whether Hong Kong enjoys sufficient autonomy from Beijing, with sanctions for Chinese officials who undermine Hong Kongers' freedom. A similar bill is working its way through the US Senate.

"It's a good step because Hong Kong can't do it alone," Ms Leung said.

"If China keeps continuing to undermine human rights and rule of law, the world needs to give them sanctions.

"I really hope that Australia can join together with Hong Kong to not only condemn the Hong Kong government and Beijing government but send a strong message to Hong Kong and Beijing they cannot get away with it."

Ms Leung defended the vandalism of city infrastructure by protesters in recent weeks, saying it reflected frustration that the Hong Kong authorities had ignored their claims and had been spurred by the hardline tactics of the police and government-backed armed mobs.

"Nobody in Hong Kong wanted to escalate our actions," she said.
description: Bonnie Leung is warning Australian MPs that the world needs to stake a stand against China over its treatment of Hong Kong.
